description: TO AMEND THE HOUSE ANSWER TO THE PRESIDENT'S SPEECH, BY ELIMINATING THE REFERENCE TO THE EXPRESSION OF INDIGNATION AT THE DEROGATORY REMARKS MADE BY THE PRESIDENT OF THE EXECUTIVE DIRECTORY OF FRANCE IN HIS SPEECH TO THE MINISTER OF THE U.S., SUBSTITUTING THEREFORE A MORE DIPLOMATIC REFERENCES TO THE SPEECH AS "TO EVINCE A LACK OF KNOWLEDGE OF THE OPINIONS OF OUR CONSTITUENTS."
TO AMEND THE HOUSE ANSWER TO THE PRESIDENT'S SPEECH, BY ELIMINATING CERTAIN REFERENCES TO RELATIONS WITH FRANCE.
TO ORDER THE MAIN QUESTION ON CONSIDERATION OF THE HOUSE ANSWER TO THE PRESIDENT'S MESSAGE.
TO AMEND THE HOUSE ANSWER TO THE PRESIDENT'S SPEECH, SO AS TO OBJECT TO THE EXPRESSION "MUTUAL SPIRIT OF CONCILIATION" IN RELATION TO FRANCE.
TO AMEND THE HOUSE ANSWER TO THE PRESIDENT'S SPEECH, TO ACKNOWLEDGE THE PRESIDENT'S APPROACH TO A FRESH ATTEMPT AT NEGOTIATION WITH FRANCE.
TO AMEND THE HOUSE ANSWER TO THE PRESIDENT'S SPEECH, TO ELIMINATE THE WORDS "FOREIGN NATIONS" IN THE PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS SO AS NOT TO OFFEND SAID NATIONS.  (P. 1233)
TO PASS THE HOUSE ANSWER TO THE PRESIDENT'S SPEECH.
TO PASS S. 1, TO PREVENT THE EXPORTATION OF ARMS AND AMMUNITION FOR A LIMITED TIME.  (P. 267)
TO PASS THE RESOLUTION TO AUTHORIZE THE PRESIDENT TO PROVIDE GALLEYS, OR OTHER VESSELS, FOR THE DEFENSE OF OUT COAST. (P. 297)

TO AMEND H.R. 1, TO PROVIDE FOR THE FORTIFICATIONS OF PORTS AND HARBORS OF THE U.S.; BY EMPOWERING THE PRESIDENT TO AUTHORIZE A CERTAIN SUM FOR THE FORTIFICATIONS OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, WHICH SUM SHALL BE CREDITED TO THE NEW YORK DEBT.
TO ORDER THE MAIN QUESTION ON PASSAGE OF H.R. 1.  (P. 323)
TO PASS H.R. 1.  (P. 324)
TO AGREE WITH THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE IN THEIR DISAGREE- MENT TO S. 3, A BILL TO RAISE AN ADDITIONAL CORPS OF ARTILLERISTS AND ENGINEERS.

TO AGREE WITH THE REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, TO REJECT THE SIXTH AND SEVENTH SECTIONS OF H.R. 7, A BILL TO PROHIBIT CITIZENS OF THE U.S. FROM ENTERING INTO THE MILITARY SERVICE OF ANY FOREIGN STATES.
TO POSTPONE H.R. 7, A BILL TO PROHIBIT CITIZENS OF THE U.S. FROM ENTERING INTO THE MILITARY SERVICE OF ANY FOREIGN STATE.  (P. 356)
TO PASS THE RESOLUTION TO AUTHORIZE THE PRESIDENT OF THE SENATE AND SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE TO ADJOURN THE PRESENT SESSION ON THE 28TH OF JUNE.
TO AMEND S. 4, A BILL TO PROTECT THE TRADE OF THE U.S.; TO PROVIDE THAT FRIGATES SHALL NOT BE EMPLOYED AS CONVEYS TO ANY FOREIGN PORT OR PLACE.
TO AMEND S. 4, TO STRIKE THE PROVISION THAT AUTHORIZED THE PRESIDENT TO PROCURE AND EMPLOY A NUMBER OF VESSELS, NOT EXCEEDING NINE.  (P. 350)
TO AMEND S. 4, TO ELIMINATE THE WORDS "WITH-IN THE JURISDICTION OF THE UNITED STATES", SO AS TO LEAVE TO THE PRESIDENT THE EMPLOYMENT OF THE CUTTERS.  (P. 375)
TO AMEND S. 4, INCREASING THE STRENGTH OF THE CUTTERS, AND TO EXTEND THE ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION ALLOWED TO THE MEN EMPLOYED, BY AN ACT OF 1796, BE EXTENDED TO ADDITIONAL MEN EMPLOYED.
TO AMEND S. 4, BY LIMITING THE CONTINUANCE OF THE ACT TO ONE YEAR.
TO PASS S. 4.  (P. 385)
TO PASS H.R. 12, A BILL TO LAY A DUTY ON LICENSES FOR THE SALE OF WINES BY RETAIL, AND ALSO FOREIGN DISTILLED SPIRITS. (P. 391)
TO POSTPONE CONSIDERATION OF S. 4.  (P. 392)
TO ADHERE TO THE HOUSE AMENDMENT TO S. 4; TO PROHIBIT THE FRIGATES FROM BEING USED AS CONVOYS.  (P. 392)
TO RECEDE FROM THE HOUSE AMENDMENT TO S. 4, SAID AMENDMENT PROHIBITING FRIGATES FROM BEING USED AS CONVOYS.
TO AMEND H.R. 8, A BILL TO LAY A STAMP DUTY ON VELLUM, PARCHMENT, AND PAPER; TO REDUCE THE PROPOSED TAX ON CERTIFICATES OF NATURALIZATION.
TO AMEND H.R. 8, BY ELIMINATING THE EXCEPTION WHICH FAVORS PATENTS FOR MILITARY LANDS SUBJECT TO A STAMP TAX.
TO AMEND H.R. 8, BY ELIMINATING THE CLAUSE EXEMPTING BANK NOTES FROM DUTY.
TO AMEND H.R. 8, BY ELIMINATING THE CLAUSE WHICH FORBIDS RECEIVING ANY PAPER NOT LEGALLY STAMPED, IN ANY COURT OF JUSTICE, IN EVIDENCE.  (P. 432)
TO PASS H.R. 8.  (P. 433)
TO PASS THE RESOLUTION TO LAY A DUTY OF EIGHT CENTS PER BUSHEL ON SLAT.
TO AMEND H.R. 17, A BILL TO LAY AN ADDITIONAL DUTY ON SALT, BY ELIMINATING THE LIMITATION CLAUSE RELATING TO THE ALLOWING A DRAWBACK TO VESSELS EMPLOYED IN THE FISHING TRADE.
TO PASS H.R. 17, A BILL TO LAY AN ADDITIONAL DUTY ON SALT.

TO PASS THE RESOLUTION THAT A RESPECTFUL ADDRESS BE PRESENTED BY THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES TO THE PRESIDENT IN ANSWER TO HIS SPEECH TO BOTH HOUSES OF CONGRESS AT THE COMMENCEMENT OF THE PRESENT SESSION, CONTAINING ASSURANCES THAT THE HOUSE WILL TAKE INTO CONSIDERATION THE VARIOUS MATTERS RECOMMENDED TO THEIR ATTENTION.
TO PERMIT COMMITTEE TO BRING IN A BILL RESPECTING THE ARMING OF MERCHANT VESSELS.  (SPEAKER VOTING IN THE AFFIRMATIVE)
TO ORDER THIRD READING OF H.R. 25, TO SUSPEND THE SECOND SECTION OF THE ACT REGULATING FOREIGN COINS.
TO AMEND H.R. 36, A BILL TO GRANT AN ANNUITY TO THE DAUGHTERS OF THE LATE COUNT DE GRASSE;  TO ALLOW $500 PER ANNUM TO EACH OF THE FOUR DAUGHTERS FOR FIVE YEARS. (P. 808)
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF H.R. 36, TO GRANT AN ANNUITY TO THE DAUGHTERS OF THE LATE COUNT DE GRASSE. (P. 808)

TO REFER THE RESOLUTION, THAT MATTHEW LYON, A MEMBER OF THE HOUSE, COMMITTED A VIOLENT ATTACK AND GROSS INDENCENCY UPON ROGER GRISWOLD, A MEMBER, WHILE SITTING IN THE PRESENCE OF THE HOUSE, TO A COMMITTEE WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO INQUIRE INTO THE MATTER.

TO PASS THE RESOLUTION THAT THIS HOUSE BILL CONSIDER IT A HIGH BREACH OF PRIVILEGE IF EITHER OF THE MEMBERS ENTER INTO ANY PERSONAL CONTEST UNTIL A DECISION OF THE HOUSE SHALL BE HAD,  AND THAT MATHEW LYON BE CONSIDERED IN THE CUSTODY OF THE SERGEANT-AT-ARMS UNTIL THE FURTHER ORDER OF THE HOUSE.  (P. 956)
TO AUTHORIZE THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE TO EXAMINE TESTIMONY RELATING TO THE REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES RELATING TO THE RESOLUTION TO EXPEL MATTHEW LYON, A MEMBER, FROM THE HOUSE.
TO AMEND THE BREACH OF PRIVILEGE RESOLUTION, TO CONFINE THE PUNISHMENT TO A REPRIMAND BY THE SPEAKER, RATHER THAN EXPULSION.
TO PASS THE BREACH OF PRIVILEGE RESOLUTION.

TO SET ASIDE THE CONDITIONS OF THE "ACT OF LIMITATIONS", AS THEY MAY APPLY TO THE RESOLUTION TO APPOINT A COMMITTEE TO BRING IN A BILL FOR THE RELIEF OF AMY DARDEN, SO AS TO ENABLE A SETTLEMENT ON THIS CLAIM, FOR THE VALUE OF HER HORSE, ROMULUS PRESSED INTO SERVICE OF THE U.S. AND KILLED.

TO CONCUR WITH THE SELECT COMMITTEE IN THEIR DISAGREEMENT TO THE SENATE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 44, TO APPROPRIATE A SUM FOR HOLDING A TREATY WITH THE INDIANS, RESPECTING THEIR TITLE TO LANDS IN TENNESSEE AND NORTH CAROLINA; SAID AMENDMENT PROVIDES THAT THE ACT NOT BE CONSTRUED TO ADMIT AN OBLIGAT- ION ON THE PART OF THE U.S. TO EXTINGUISH INDIAN CLAIMS TO ANY LANDS LYING WITHIN THE TERRITORY OF THE UNITED STATES.

TO POSTPONE THE FURTHER CONSIDERATION OF THE REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES RELATING TO THE RESOLUTION TO EXPEL ROGER GRISWOLD AND MATTHEW LYON, WHICH SUGGESTS THAT THE RESOLUTION BE DISAGREED TO.  (P. 1063)
TO AGREE TO THE REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES, RELATING TO THE RESOLUTION TO EXPEL MATTHEW LYON AND ROGER GRISWOLD FROM THE HOUSE, WHICH SUGGESTS THAT THIS RESOLUTION BE DISAGREED TO.

TO PUT THE MAIN QUESTION ON PASSAGE OF THE RESOLUTION: "THAT ROGER GRISWOLD AND MATTHEW LYON, FOR DISORDERLY BEHAVIOR IN THIS HOUSE, ARE HIGHLY CENSURABLE, AND THAT THEY BE REPRIMANDED BY THE SPEAKER IN THE PRESENCE OF THE HOUSE.
TO POSTPONE FOR THREE WEEKS THE RESOLUTION TO INSTRUCT THE COMMITTEE OF WAYS AND MEANS TO BRING IN A BILL TO REPEAL THE ACT LAYING DUTIES ON STAMPED VELLUM, PARCHMENT AND PAPER.
TO POSTPONE THE STAMP DUTIES RESOLUTION FOR ONE WEEK. (P. 1080)
TO PASS THE STAMP DUTIES RESOLUTION.
TO PASS H.R. 56, TO REPEAL THE STAMP ACT.  (P. 1098)

TO AMEND H.R. 41, A BILL TO PROVIDE THE MEANS OF INTERCOURSE WITH FOREIGN NATIONS; BY LIMITING THE SALARIES OF MINISTERS PLENIPOTENTIARY TO LONDON, PARIS AND MADRID TO $9,000, A YR. AND ALL OTHERS TO $4,500.
TO PASS H.R. 59, A BILL SUPPLEMENTARY TO THE ACT ESTABLISH- ING THE JUDICIAL COURTS OF THE UNITED STATES.  (P. 1267)
TO POSTPONE TO MARCH 4, THE REPORT OF A SELECT COMMITTEE FOR AMENDING THE STANDING RULES OF THE HOUSE.
TO DISAGREE TO THE LAST TWO MOTIONS CONTAINED IN THE SELECT COMMITTEE REPORT REGARDING THE AMENDING OF THE STANDING RULES OF THE HOUSE.  (P. 1295)
TO PASS THE RESOLUTION THAT THE PRESIDENT OF THE U.S. BE REQUESTED TO COMMUNICATE TO THIS HOUSE, THE INSTRUCTIONS TO AND DISPATCHES FROM, THE ENVOYS EXTRADINARY OF THE U.S. TO THE FRENCH REPUBLIC.

TO AMEND H.R. 79, SUPPLEMENTARY TO THE ACT PROVIDING FOR THE FURTHER DEFENSE OF THE PORTS AND HARBORS OF THE U.S.; BY ELIMINATING THE PORTS AT WHICH THE MONEY APPROPRIATED SHOULD BE EXPENDED, AND ALLOWING THE PRESIDENT THE POWER TO EXPEND SAID SUMS WHEN AND HOW HE DEEMS PROPER.
TO AMEND H.R. 80, TO PROVIDE AN ADDITIONAL REGIMENT OF ARTILLERY AND ENGINEERS, BY LIMITING THE ACT TO ONE YEAR.

TO AMEND THE HOUSE BILL TO PROVIDE FOR AN ADDITIONAL ARMAMENT FOR THE FURTHER PROTECTION OF THE TRADE OF THE UNITED STATES, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES; BY REDUCING THE NUMBER OF VESSELS TO BE USED AS CONVOYS.
TO AMEND THE HOUSE BILL TO PROVIDE FOR THE FURTHER PROTECTION OF THE U.S. TRADE; BY INCLUDING THE PROVISION THAT THE FRIGATES SHALL NOT BE EMPLOYED AS CONVOY TO ANY FOREIGN PORT.
TO ORDER THIRD READING OF S. 18, A BILL TO ESTABLISH AN EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT TO BE THE DEPARTMENT OF THE NAVY.
TO AGREE WITH THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE IN THEIR DISAGREEMENT TO VARIOUS SENATE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 66, A BILL RESPECTING THE COMPENSATION OF CLERKS.  (P. 1554)

TO AGREE WITH THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE IN THEIR DISAGREEMENT WITH THE SENATE RESOLUTION GRANTING LEAVE TO MR. PINCKNEY, LATE AMBASSADOR TO GREAT BRITAIN AND SPAIN, TO RECEIVE CERTAIN PRESENTS FROM THE COURTS ON HIS TAKING LEAVE.  (P. 1593)

TO REFER THE RESOLUTIONS OF CAPTAIN MAGNIEN'S COMPANY OF GRENADIERS AT PORTSMOUTH VIRGINIA, EXPRESSIVE OF THEIR OPINION OF GOVERNMENT MEASURES, AND OF THE PRESENT SITUATION BETWEEN THIS COUNTRY AND FRANCE, TO THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE ON THE STATE OF THE UNION.
TO AMEND S. 19, A BILL TO AUTHORIZE THE PRESIDENT TO RAISE A PROVISIONAL ARMY OF 20,000 MEN; BY PROVIDING THAT THE ACT GO INTO EFFECT BEFORE THE NEXT SESSION OF CONGRESS.
TO AMEND S. 19, BY STIPULATING CONDITIONS UNDER WHICH THE PRESIDENT MAY RAISE AN ARMY, THEREBY ELIMINATING THE AUTHORITY OF THE PRESIDENT TO RAISE THE ARMY AS HE SEES FIT. (P. 689)
TO AMEND S. 19, BY REDUCING THE NUMBER OF MEN TO 10,000 FROM 20,000.  (P. 1769)
TO AMEND S. 19, BY REPLACING THE PHRASE "COMPANY OR COMPANIES OF VOLUNTEERS" WITH THE PHRASE "MILITIA CORPS" ESTABLISHED BY LAW IN ANY STATE.  (P. 1770)
TO AGREE TO THE AMENDMENT TO S. 19, TO STRIKE THE WORDS "WITHIN THREE YEARS AFTER THE PASSING OF THIS ACT", AND INSERT "BEFORE THE NEXT SESSION OF CONGRESS."
TO PASS S. 19.  (P. 1772)

TO AMEND H.R. 91, TO PROVIDE COMPENSATION FOR THE MARSHALLS, CLERKS, ATTORNEYS, JURORS AND WITNESSES IN THE COURTS OF THE UNITED STATES AND TO REPEAL CERTAIN PARTS OF ACTS THEREIN MENTIONED, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES; BY STRIKING THE PROVISION FOR AN EXTRA $300 COMPENSATION TO ALL MARSHALLS.

TO AMEND H.R. 91, TO PROVIDE COMPENSATION TO MARCHALLS, CLERKS, ATTORNEYS, JURORS, AND WITNESSES IN THE COURTS OF THE UNITED STATES, AND TO REPEAL CERTAIN PARTS OF ACTS THEREIN MENTIONED, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES; BY STRIKING THE PROVISION FOR AN EXTRA COMPENSATION TO CERTAIN NAMED ATTORNEYS.
TO RECOMMIT H.R. 94, TO SECURE OR REMOVE ALIENS FROM THE UNITED STATES, TO COMMITTEE, AND TO MAKE IT THE ORDER OF THE DAY.  (P. 1796)

TO AMEND S. 22, FOR THE MORE EFFECTUAL PROTECTION OF THE COMMERCE AND COASTS OF THE U.S. BY MAKING THE INSTRUCTIONS GIVEN THE COMMANDERS OF OUR VESSESL, GENERAL AGAINST ALL CRUISERS, AS WELL AS AGAINST THE FRENCH.
TO ORDER THIRD READING OF S. 22.
TO ORDER THIRD READING OF S. 22.
TO PASS H.R. 102, TO SUSPEND THE COMMERCIAL INTERCOURSE BETWEEN THE U.S. AND THE FRENCH REPUBLIC.

TO AMEND H.R. 73, A BILL TO MAKE APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE MILITARY ESTABLISHMENT FOR THE YEAR, 1798, BY CONSOLIDATING CERTAIN APPROPRIATIONS, INCREASING APPROPRIATIONS FOR SOME DEPARTMENTS, AND ADDING AN APPROPRIATION FOR CONTINGENCIES.

TO PASS H.R. 100, A BILL TO REGULATE THE COMPENSATION OF THE OFFICERS EMPLOYED IN THE COLLECTION OF THE INTERNAL REVENUE OF THE UNITED STATES AND TO PROVIDE FOR THE MORE EFFECTUAL SETTLEMENT OF THEIR ACCOUNTS.
TO AUTHORIZE THE COMMITTEE FOR THE PROTECTION OF COMMERCE AND DEFENCE OF THE COUNTRY TO REPORT BY BILL OR OTHER-WISE ON THE RESOLUTION TO GRANT GENERAL REPRISALS, LETTERS OF MARQUE, ETC.
TO AMEND H.R. 105, A BILL TO PROVIDE FOR THE VALUATION OF HOUSES AND LANDS, AND FOR THE ENUMERATION OF SLAVES; BY INCLUDING AS TAXABLE ALL PROPERTY WHICH IS TAXABLE BY THE RESPECTIVE STATES.

TO AMEND H.R. 109, A BILL TO AUTHORIZE THE DEFENSE OF U.S., MERCHANT VESSELS, AGAINST FRENCH DEPREDATIONS; TO GIVE COMMANDERS OF U.S. VESSELS THE RIGHT TO ATTACK ANY FRENCH VESSEL WHICH MAY HAVE MADE A CAPTURE OF ANY U.S. SHIP.
TO PASS H.R. 105 TO PROVIDE FOR THE VALUATION OF HOUSES AND LANDS, AND THE ENUMERATION OF SLAVES WITHIN THE U.S.
TO PASS H.R. 107, A BILL TO PROVIDE ARMS FOR THE MILITIA THROUGHOUT THE U.S.  (P. 1938)
TO AMEND H.R. 111, TO SUPPLEMENT AND AMEND "AN ACT AUTHORIZING THE PRESIDENT TO RAISE A PROVISIONAL ARMY"; BY AUTHORIZING THE PRESIDENT TO APPOINT SUCH OFFICERS AS HE DEEMS NECESSARY.
TO AMEND H.R. 111, BY CONFINING THE LOAN OF ARMS TO PIECES OF ARTILLARY ALONE.
TO PASS H.R. 111.
TO PASS S. 24, TO SECURE OR REMOVE ALIENS FROM THE U.S.
TO AMEND H.R. 113, A BILL TO ENABLE THE PRESIDENT TO BORROW MONEY FOR THE PUBLIC SERVICE; BY LIMITING THE AMOUNT OF THE LOAN AND TO STIPULATE CONDITIONS FOR ITS USE.  (P. 12042)
TO AMEND H.R. 113, A BILL AUTHORIZING THE PRESIDENT TO BORROW MONEY FOR THE PUBLIC SERVICE; TO LIMIT THE RATE OF INTEREST TO BE PAID.
TO AMEND H.R. 116, A BILL TO LAY AND COLLECT DIRECT TAXES WITHIN THE U.S.; BY MAKING THE TAX EQUAL ON HOUSES AND LAND, AND ALL OTHER IMPROVEMENTS.  (P. 2059)
TO AMEND H.R. 116, BY PROVIDING TO TAX EACH SLAVE AT A RATE OF FIFTY CENTS.
TO AMEND H.R. 116, A BILL TO MAKE THE TAX ON HOUSES AND LAND BEAR A PROPROTION TO EACH OTHER, AND TO PREVENT LAND FROM BEING TAXED HIGHER THAN THE RATE LAID UPON HOUSES OF THE LOWEST VALUE.
TO PASS H.R. 116.  (P. 2066)
TO AMEND S. 22, SO AS TO ELIMINATE THE SECTION AUTHORIZING THE FITTING OUT OF PRIVATEERS TO CRUISE AGAINST FRENCH VESSELS IN EVERY PART OF THE OCEAN.
TO AMEND S. 22, SO AS TO AUTHORIZE THE CAPTURE OF ALL FRENCH VESSELS.  (P. 2082)
TO PASS THE RESOLTUION TO REQUEST THE PRESIDENT TO INSTRUCT THE ENVOY AT PARIS TO PROCEED IN THE NEGOTIATIONS WITH FRANCE, AND TO CONCLUDE A TREATY CONSISTENT WITH THE INSTRUCTIONS OF THE PRESIDENT.

TO AMEND THE HOUSE RESOLUTION TO AUTHORIZE THE PRESIDENT TO RAISE ADDITIONAL COMPANIES OF THE MILITARY ESTABLISHMENT DURING THE CONTINUANCE OF THE EXISTING DIFFERENCES BETWEEN THE U.S. AND FRANCE; BY INCREASING THE REGIMENTS TO BE ADDED, FROM EIGHT TO TWELVE.  (SPEAKER VOTING IN THE AFFIRMATIVE).  (P. 2092)
TO REJECT S. 31, IN ADDITION TO THE ACT FOR THE PUNISHMENT OF CERTAIN CRIMES AGAINST THE U.S.
TO PASS S. 29, DECLARING THE TREATY BETWEEN FRANCE AND THE U.S., VOID.
TO AMEND H.R. 125, A BILL TO AUGMENT THE ARMY, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES; BY REDUCING THE NUMBER OF ADDITIONAL REGIMENTS TO EIGHT FROM TWELVE.  (P. 2131)
TO PASS H.R. 125, TO AUGMENT THE ARMY, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES.
TO AMEND S. 31, TO PROVIDE THAT "IN ALL CASES ARISING UNDER THIS ACT, THE JURY SHALL BE JUDGE OF THE LAW, AS WELL AS THE FACT."

TO AMEND S. 31, BY ELIMINATING THE CLAUSE WHICH WOULD PUNISH ANY PERSON WHO WRITES, PRINTS, SPEAKES OR THREATENS AN OFFICER OR PERSON IN PUBLIC TRUST, WITH ANY DANGER TO HIS CHARACTER, PERSON, OR ESTATE.
TO PASS S. 31.
TO PASS H.R. 128, RESPECTING BALANCES DUE FROM CERTAIN STATES.
TO PASS S. 35, A BILL TO ENCOURAGE THE CAPTURE OF FRENCH ARMED VESSELS BY ARMED VESSELS BELONGING TO UNITED STATES CITIZENS.  (P. 2178)
TO ORDER THIRD READING OF H.R. 131, TO SUPPLEMENT THE ACT FOR SUSPENDING THE COMMERCIAL INTERCOURSE BETWEEN THE U.S. AND FRANCE.  (P. 2179)

TO PASS THE RESOLUTION THAT A COMMITTEE BE APPOINTED TO PREPARE AND BRING IN A BILL FOR GIVING A BOUNTY ON THE CAPTURE OF FRENCH ARMED SHIPS BY ARMED SHIPS OWNED BY A CITIZEN OF THE UNITED STATES.  (P. 2181)
TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION TO PRINT 20,000 COPIES OF THE ALIEN AND SEDITION LAWS; TO PROVIDE THAT THE CONSTITUTION SHALL BE PRINTED WITH SAID LAWS.
TO AMEND THE PRINTING RESOLUTION BY ENUMERATING SEVERAL CLAUSES AND ARTICLES OF THE CONSTITUTION TO BE PRINTED WITH SAID LAWS.
TO AMEND THE PRINTING RESOLUTION SO AS TO HAVE PRINTED ALL AMENDMENTS OF THE CONSTITUTION.
TO PASS THE PRINTING RESOLUTION.
TO RECEIVE THE REPORT OF THE MANAGERS OF THE HOUSE CONCERN- ING THE IMPEACHMENT OF WILLIAM BLOUNT.

TO PASS THE RESOLUTION TO APPOINT A COMMITTEE TO CONSIDER THE PROPRIETY OF AMENDING THE ACT FOR THE PUNISHMENT OF CERTAIN CRIMES AGAINST THE U.S., SO AS TO PROVIDE A PENALTY FOR ANY CITIZEN WHO SHALL USURP THE EXECUTIVE AUTHORITY OF THE GOVERNMENT.

TO AMEND H.R. 141, A BILL TO PUNISH CERTAIN CRIMES THERE-IN SPECIFIED RELATING TO USURPATION OF EXECUTIVE AUTHORITY; TO MAKE GUILTY ANY PERSON WITH "INTENT TO DEFEAT OR IMPEDE THE AMICABLE ADJUSTMENT OF SAID DISPUTES OR CONTROVERSIES." (P. 2590)
TO AMEND H.R. 141  A BILL TO PREVENT THE OPERATION OF THIS LAW FROM REACHING INDIVIDUALS IN THEIR ATTEMPTS TO OBTAIN JUSTICE FROM A FOREIGN GOVERNMENT.
TO RECOMMIT H.R. 141, TO A SELECT COMMITTEE WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO MODIFY TO MAKE BILL MORE ACCEPTABLE.
TO PASS H.R. 135, A BILL TO ESTABLISH A UNIFORM SYSTEM OF BANKRUPTCY THROUGHOUT THE U.S.  (P. 2676)
TO AMEND H.R. 141, TO PROVIDE THAT THIS ACT SHALL NOT ABRIDGE THE RIGHT OF A CITIZEN TO APPLY TO A FOREIGN GOVERNMENT FOR JUSTICE.  (P. 2679)
TO AMEND H.R. 141, SO AS TO CONFINE THE OPERATION OF THE BILL MARCH 3, 1800, WHEN IT SHALL BECOME NULL AND VOID.

TO AMEND H.R. 141, BY MAKING THE LAW APPLY TO ANY PERSON HAVING INTENT TO USURP THE AUTHORITY OF THE GOVERNMENT BY INTERMEDDLING IN ANY DESPUTE OR NEGOTIATION BETWEEN THE U.S. AND A FOREIGN NATION, OR WITH INTENT TO DEFEAT OR COUNTERACT ANY MEASURE OF THE U.S. GOVERNMENT.
TO AMEND H.R. 141, TO INCLUDE UNDER THE ACT "ANY OFFICER OR AGENT" OF THE U.S. GOVERNMENT, AS WELL AS ANY CITIZEN. (P. 2681)
TO PASS H.R. 141.

TO AGREE WITH COMMITTEE IN THEIR DISAGREEMENT TO THE SENATE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 137, AN ACT PROVIDING FOR THE ENUMERATION OF THE INHABITANTS OF THE U.S.; AMENDMENT TO SUBSTITUTE THE WORDS "APRIL 1800", FOR "NEXT MAY".

TO AMEND H.R. 140, A BILL TO FURTHER SUSPEND OUR COMMERCIAL INTERCOURSE WITH FRANCE, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES; BY ELIMINATING PRESIDENTIAL AUTHORITY TO SUSPEND COMMERCIAL INTERCOURSE BETWEEN THE U.S. AND CERTAIN WEST INDIES PORTS.
TO AMEND H.R. 140, SO AS TO GIVE THE PRESIDENT AUTHORITY TO SUSPEND COMMERCIAL INTERCOURSE WITH CERTAIN PORTS.
TO AMEND H.R. 140 SO AS TO CONFINE THE OPERATION OF THIS ACT TO MARCH 3, 1800.
TO AMEND H.R. 140, TO PREVENT THE LAW OPERATING TO SUSPEND THE COMMERCE OF THE WESTERN COUNTRY BY THE MISSISSIPPI.
TO RECOMMIT H.R. 140 TO COMMITTEE WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO EXPUNGE A PROVISO EXCLUDING THE PORT OF NEW ORLEANS FROM ITS OPERATION.
TO PASS H.R. 140.
TO REFER THE RESOLUTION, TO INQUIRE INTO THE EXPEDIENCY OF AUGMENTING THE SALARIES OF THE OFFICERS IN THE EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT, TO THE COMMITTEE ON WAYS AND MEANS.

TO REFER TO THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, A PETITION FROM THE INHABITANTS OF AMELIA COUNTY, VIRGINIA, CENSURING MANY MEASURES OF THE GENERAL GOVERNMENT, COMPLAINING THE BRITISH TREATY FOLLOWS TOO MUCH THE POLICY OF THE BRITISH GOVERNMENT AND PRAYING THE REPEAL OF THE ALIEN AND SEDITION LAWS AND THE PROVISIONAL ARMY BILL.
TO AMEND H.R. 138, A BILL TO AMEND THE STAMP ACT; TO ALLOW A COMPENSATION TO SUPERVISORS FOR STAMPING AND SELLING STAMPS.
TO AMEND H.R. 143, A BILL TO AMEND THE ACT FOR VALUING LANDS AND DWELLING HOUSES, AND FOR THE ENUMERATION OF SLAVES; BY ELIMINATING THE PAY INCREASE FOR ASSESSORS.
TO AGREE TO THE SENATE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 140, TO ELIMINATE THE SECTIONS GIVING THE PRESIDENT POWER SUSPEND COMMERCIAL INTERCOURSE WITH CERTAIN SPANISH AND DUTCH PORTS. (P. 2822)
TO AMEND H.R. 150, A BILL TO AUGMENT THE NAVY AND TO FIX THE PAY OF THE CAPTAINS OF VESSELS OF WAR; BY ELIMINATING AUTHORITY TO CONSTRUCT SIX SHIPS OF WAR OF A CERTAIN SIZE. (P. 2856)
TO PASS H.R. 150, A BILL TO AUGMENT THE NAVY AND TO FIX THE PAY OF THE CAPTAINS OF VESSELS OF WAR.
TO REFER TO THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, A PETITION FROM A NUMBER OF ALIENS, NATIVES OF IRELAND, PRAYING FOR A REPEAL OF THE ALIEN LAW.

TO PASS THE RESOLUTION THAT THE PRESIDENT LAY BEFORE THE HOUSE ANY INFORMATION TOUCHING THE SUSPENSION OF THE DECREE OF THE FRENCH DIRECTORY RELATIVE TO THE CITIZENS OF NEUTRAL NATIONS FOUND ON BOARD BRITISH SHIPS OF WAR.

TO AGREE TO THE REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE TO ELIMINATE THE FIRST SECTION OF H.R. 139, FOR ENCOURAGING THE CAPTURE OF FRENCH PRIVATEERS, BY ALLOWING A BOUNTY ON GUNS, THEREBY REPEALING THE BILL.  (P. 2953)
TO PASS THE RESOLUTION TO EXPEL MATTHEW LYON FROM THE HOUSE FOR CERTAIN SPECIFIED SEDITIONS AND LIBELOUS ACTIONS.

TO CONCUR IN THE SENATE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 143, TO AMEND THE ACT PROVIDING FOR THE VALUATION OF LANDS AND HOUSES, AND FOR THE ENUMERATION OF SLAVES; WHICH AMENDMENT AUTHORIZES THE SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY TO INCREASE THE PAY OF ASSESSORS.
TO PASS THE RESOLUTION THAT IT IS INEXPEDIENT TO REPEAL "AN ACT CONCERNING ALIENS".
TO PASS THE RESOLUTION THAT IT IS INEXPEDIENT TO REPEAL "AN ACT IN ADDITION TO 'AN ACT FOR THE PUNISHMENT OF CERTAIN CRIMES AGAINST THE UNITED STATES'".

TO AMEND THE FIRST SECTION OF THE SENATE BILL FOR THE BETTER ORGANIZATION OF U. S. TROOPS, AND FOR OTHE PURPOSES, BY STRIKING THE PHRASE "THE NUMBER OF PRIVATES RAISED SHALL NOT EXCEED THE NUMBER FOR WHICH PROVISION HATH BEEN MADE BY LAW", AND TO INSERT "NO PART OF THE INCREASE PROVIDED BY THIS ACT SHALL TAKE PLACE."
TO AMEND S. 38, TO BETTER ORGANIZE THE TROOPS OF THE U.S., BY PROVIDING THAT NO ADDITIONAL FORCE BE RAISED UNLESS FURTHER PROVISION IS MADE OR WAR BREAKS OUT.  (P. 3018)
TO PASS H.R. 158, TO AUGMENT THE SALARIES OF CERTAIN EXECUTIVE OFFICERS.  (P. 3019)
TO PASS H.R. 163, FOR THE RELIEF OF COMFORT SANDS.
